video.title: E-commerce Website With Django and Vue Tutorial (Django Rest Framework)
video.description:
Learn how to build an e-commerce website using Django and Vue from scratch. Django uses Python Vue uses JavaScript.

Django Rest Framework is used to build the API and backend.
The frontend is a separate Vue project. To handle the payments, we implement Stripe.

✏️ The course was developed by CodeWithStein. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/CodeWithStein
🐦 CodeWithStein on twitter: https://twitter.com/codewithstein

💻 Code - Django: https://github.com/SteinOveHelset/djackets_django
💻 Code - Vue: https://github.com/SteinOveHelset/djackets_vue

🔗 Live demo: https://djackets.codewithstein.com/
🔗 The files and commands I use on the server can be found in the repository here: https://github.com/SteinOveHelset/djackets_django/tree/main/extras

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:00:55) Demo
⌨️ (0:02:41) Install and setup (Django)
⌨️ (0:11:39) Install and setup (Vue)
⌨️ (0:15:49) Include Font Awesome
⌨️ (0:16:28) Set up the base template
⌨️ (0:22:55) Create django app and models for products
⌨️ (0:33:19) Create serializer and views for the products
⌨️ (0:39:50) Create simple front page (latest products)
⌨️ (0:45:40) View a product 
⌨️ (0:55:57) Sette opp Vuex / State
⌨️ (0:57:27) Make it possible to add to cart
⌨️ (1:05:31) Implement a loading bar
⌨️ (1:08:59) Set document title (All pages)
⌨️ (1:09:58) Make it possible to view a category
⌨️ (1:21:07) Add search functionality
⌨️ (1:28:07) View cart
⌨️ (1:34:34) Change contents of cart
⌨️ (1:38:14) Make it possible to sign up
⌨️ (1:43:34) Make it possible to log in
⌨️ (1:48:38) Create a simple my account page
⌨️ (1:53:24) Proceed to checkout (Authentication)
⌨️ (1:58:59) Create a simple success page
⌨️ (2:14:29) Show my orders on the my account page
⌨️ (2:18:41) Deploy Django 
⌨️ (2:40:39) Deploy Vue (Generate files locally, Send files to server, Set up nginx virtual host)

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Amethyst Radcliffe
topLevelComment.text:
Thank you so much for this!  It was really helpful!
I am running into an issue with authentication.  The localStorage will not let go of the token and when I click logout, and refresh the home page, it still shows I'm logged in.  My guess is something is rewriting the token and is not being reset.  I watched the part about initializing the store, creating the login, and creating the account page like 6 times and cant catch where the mistake is.
The browser is not throwing any errors, and all other functionality works fine.  I just cant seem to clear the token.  Logging out does redirect me to the home page, but the token is still there and shows that the user is logged in.  Does anyone know how to get past this?

replies.author: Amethyst Radcliffe
replies.text: @Aaron Lequia yes! It’s embarrassing, but it was a spelling error in the variable name 😅.  At least I found it! I downloaded a new IDE to help catch that kind of mistake early on.

replies.author: Aaron Lequia
replies.text: Did you ever figure this out? I have the same issue

topLevelComment.author: Mateusz Ł.

Next time you make a tutorial instead of making almost 3h of content make a 5 min one explaining from where you can copy all of your work.

topLevelComment.author: Nathan Leopold
topLevelComment.text: I had some issues with search. I kept getting a 405 error. Fixed it by adding GET to the @api_view decorator. @api_view(['POST', 'GET']).   No idea why this worked cause I pretty sure it is a post request, but this solved my issue and now I'm getting good search results.

replies.author: dandelion0331
replies.text: make sure the url in search endpoint(django product/url.py ), and vue route as well as axios post request is consistent. check the trailing slashes. if you put a trailing slash in api endpoint and you're missing one in axios request in Search component, you will get this error.

topLevelComment.author: Jasonadki
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone who followed this video and then moved onto a new db structure where you added/deleted apps and continue to see the following error on the admin login page:
Django custom user model in admin, relation “auth_user” does not exist.

Make sure to update your "asgi.py" and "wsgi.py" to point to the new "settingsprod"

Then restart your supervisorctl and nginx service

topLevelComment.text: [1] Great work, thank you! [2] I try follow the tutorial (Debian bullseye), I am near at the finish now. I had some troubles and one of them makes me not happy. Once I have implemented Login, sometimes when I switch between anonymous and saved user I have the added item inside the cart, but this item has Product == null. When I run debugger before and after the adding command, the proper Product is still included. Nothing appears in Django console, in Vue console, in Javascript console. Seems that restart will repair it, but forever? for some time? I have some theories about it: 1) Should the `cart` variable be it each component? is this not a risk? Couldn't we have single variable in vuex store only? and the same with functions which sum items count or total price - such duplicate code could be removed; 2) some troubles with corrupted LocalStorage?; 3) Is this not an internal bug in Vue reactivity? -- Number (3) is a worsest one. Can I really believe that JavaScript+Vue are mature enough? I just want to do things better and easier as in plain Django. But I'm unsure now again. Espec. when I read such articles about JavaScript (what the stability of code could be if we build on base with such problems, undocumented and unknown for much developers?): https://jakearchibald.com/2021/export-default-thing-vs-thing-as-default/

topLevelComment.author: Goldfish brain John
topLevelComment.text:
For those who cannot get the authtoken because "non_field_errors", Follow the instructions below.

put the code in the settings.py

REST_FRAMEWORK = {
    'DEFAULT_AUTHENTICATION_CLASSES': (
        'rest_framework.authentication.TokenAuthentication',
    ),
}


Add rest_framework.authentication.TokenAuthentication to Django REST Framework authentication strategies tuple.

Because without it, the /api/v1/token/login endpoint cannot work!

Then, run python manage.py makemigrations and python manage.py migrate, this will create auth and authtoken tables.

After creating auth and authtoken tables, you should be able to create a user and get token from the /api/v1/token/login endpoint.

topLevelComment.author: Goldfish brain John
topLevelComment.text:
For everyone who encountered the problem of  "File name includes path elements", here is the solution



I encountered this problem yesterday just like you and I found a solution just a minute ago.

The problem was caused by the file name just as the Django debug mode tried to tell you, "File name 'uploads/winter3.jpg' includes path elements".

"uploads/winter3.jpg" is not a legal path name, so what we need to do is to remove "uploads/" from the name of the image, make the name to be "winter3.jpe" and that is really simple.

Here is the code of the solution for this problem

def make_thumbnail(self, image, size=(300, 200)):
    img = Image.open(image)
    img.convert('RGB')
    img.thumbnail(size)

    thumb_io = BytesIO()
    img.save(thumb_io, 'JPEG', qulity=85)

    # just add replace("uploads/","") after the image.name
    thumbnail = File(thumb_io, name=image.name.replace("uploads/",""))
    return thumbnail

Hope this can help you!

return _bootstrap._gcd_import(name[level:], package, level)
File “<frozen import lib._bootsrap>”, line 1030, in _gcd_import
File “<frozen import lib._bootsrap>”, line 1007, in _find_and_load

replies.author: goodyonsen1
replies.text:
OK, I got it figured:
It’s because the “_” underscore. When he pip install, he uses “-“ dash like:
"pip install django-rest-framework”. But in settings.py he appends INSTALLED_APPS list this:
‘rest_framework’, 
‘rest_framework.authtoken’ 
So if you encounter same traceback, just make sure you use underscore in settings.py

replies.author: Grigorij Abramov
replies.text:
Step1:
pip install django-cors-headers
Step2:
Go to settings.py and INSTALLED_APPS  must look like this:
"INSTALLED_APPS = [
    'django.contrib.admin',
    'django.contrib.auth',
    'django.contrib.contenttypes',
    'django.contrib.sessions',
    'django.contrib.messages',
    'django.contrib.staticfiles',
    'rest_framework',
    'rest_framework.authtoken',
    'corsheaders',
    'djoser',
    'product',
]"

replies.author: Shahriar Siddik
replies.text: you will need django-cors-headers installed through pip or pipenv for the project

topLevelComment.text:
After adding that line at 37:35, the app crashed:

It gave the following error. Why is that?

Exception in thread django-main-thread:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/xxxxx/VueDjangoEcommerce/environment/lib/python3.9/site-packages/django/urls/resolvers.py", line 600, in url_patterns
    iter(patterns)
TypeError: 'module' object is not iterable

django.core.exceptions.ImproperlyConfigured: The included URLconf xxx does not appear to have any patterns in it

replies.author: Liefwerk
replies.text: @Harrison Fok Also the error says that you don't have a urlpatterns list in your urls.py in the PRODUCT folder. That might be the issue.

replies.author: Liefwerk
replies.text:
​@Harrison Fok what you pasted here is what I have in my urls.py file in the MAIN folder not in the PRODUCT folder. can you paste what you have in the urls.py in the PRODUCT folder ?

here's a tree to visualize it:
djackets_django
     __init__.py
    ...
    settings.py
    urls.py << this is the urls.py in the MAIN folder
product
    migrations
    __init__.py
    models.py
    ...
    urls.py << this is the urls.py in the PRODUCT folder

replies.author: Harrison Fok
replies.text:
​@Liefwerk The new line that caused the error was: path('api/v1/', include('product.urls')). Once I remove it, there's no errors

This is the urls.py inside the product folder:

from django.conf import settings
from django.conf.urls.static import static
from django.contrib import admin
from django.urls import path, include

urlpatterns = [
    path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
    path('api/v1/', include('djoser.urls')),
    path('api/v1/', include('djoser.urls.authtoken')),
    path('api/v1/', include('product.urls'))
] + static(settings.MEDIA_URL, document_root=settings.MEDIA_ROOT)

Errors:
TypeError: 'module' object is not iterable
...
django.core.exceptions.ImproperlyConfigured: The included URLconf '<module 'product.urls' from '/Users/xxxxx/djackets_django/product/urls.py'>' does not appear to have any patterns in it. If you see valid patterns in the file then the issue is probably caused by a circular import.

replies.author: Liefwerk
replies.text: If you remove that new line, do you still have the error ? Can you show the content of the urls.py file inside the product folder ?

replies.author: Yavor Paunov
replies.text: @Liefwerk thanks a lot for pointing me in the right direction. Actually in my case replacing the "localhost" with "127.0.0.1" in the CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS resolved the issue.

replies.author: Liefwerk
replies.text: @Yavor Paunov Did you add the right url to the CORS_ALLOWED_ORIGINS list in settings.py ? It should be localhost:8080

replies.author: Dave Budah
replies.text: Usually, since they will have built the project earlier before redoing it in the recording they keep the code next to them to copy and paste, so they don't waste your time typing it all out. It helps shorten the video length plus minimizes errors during recording.
